articles.headline: Charges of Ukrainian Meddling? A Russian Operation, U.S. Intelligence Says
articles.snippet: Moscow has run a yearslong operation to blame Ukraine for its own 2016 election interference. Republicans have used similar talking points to defend President Trump in impeachment proceedings.
articles.abstract: Moscow has run a yearslong operation to blame Ukraine for its own 2016 election interference. Republicans have used similar talking points to defend President Trump in impeachment proceedings.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Republicans have sought for weeks amid the impeachment inquiry to shift attention to President Trump’s demands that Ukraine investigate any 2016 election meddling, defending it as a legitimate concern while Democrats accuse Mr. Trump of pursuing fringe theories for his benefit.
articles.byline: By Julian E. Barnes and Matthew Rosenberg

articles.headline: Canadian Official Calls for Removal of Key Software From 737 Max
articles.snippet: “MCAS has to go,” a manager at Canada’s aviation regulator said in an email to global peers, referring to software in the Boeing plane.
articles.abstract: “MCAS has to go,” a manager at Canada’s aviation regulator said in an email to global peers, referring to software in the Boeing plane.
articles.lead_paragraph: A manager at Canada’s aviation regulator believes that Boeing should remove software that played a role in two deadly crashes of its 737 Max before the plane is cleared to fly again, according to emails between global aviation regulators this week that were reviewed by The New York Times.
articles.byline: By Natalie Kitroeff and David Gelles

articles.headline: Russia Inquiry Review Is Said to Criticize F.B.I. but Rebuff Claims of Biased Acts
articles.snippet: A watchdog report will portray the pursuit of a wiretap of an ex-Trump adviser as sloppy, but it also debunks some accusations by Trump allies of F.B.I. wrongdoing.
articles.abstract: A watchdog report will portray the pursuit of a wiretap of an ex-Trump adviser as sloppy, but it also debunks some accusations by Trump allies of F.B.I. wrongdoing.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A highly anticipated report by the Justice Department’s inspector general is expected to sharply criticize lower-level F.B.I. officials as well as bureau leaders involved in the early stages of the Trump-Russia investigation, but to absolve the top ranks of abusing their powers out of bias against President Trump, according to people briefed on a draft.
articles.byline: By Adam Goldman and Charlie Savage

articles.headline: Bloomberg Prepares Huge TV Blitz, Reserving $30 Million in Ads
articles.snippet: Michael R. Bloomberg, the former mayor of New York City and expected presidential candidate, is buying ads in more than two dozen states.
articles.abstract: Michael R. Bloomberg, the former mayor of New York City and expected presidential candidate, is buying ads in more than two dozen states.
articles.lead_paragraph: Michael R. Bloomberg, the billionaire former mayor of New York City, spent at least $30 million on Friday for a single week of television ads, a show of financial force that signals his willingness to use his vast personal fortune to reshape the Democratic presidential race.
articles.byline: By Shane Goldmacher

articles.headline: ‘Tuesday Afternoon Impeachment’ Is as Big as ‘Monday Night Football’
articles.snippet: TV’s impeachment drama is drawing big ratings, but a Democratic debate on MSNBC sank to a viewership low.
articles.abstract: TV’s impeachment drama is drawing big ratings, but a Democratic debate on MSNBC sank to a viewership low.
articles.lead_paragraph: On the third day that impeachment hearings blanketed American televisions, from morning talk shows to late-night monologues, Representative Devin Nunes came out with a public service announcement.
articles.byline: By Michael M. Grynbaum

articles.headline: A Senate Trial Could Put Trump’s Use of Aggressive Defense Tactics to Their Biggest Test
articles.snippet: The president’s campaign against the Mueller report and its author is a road map of what is likely to lie ahead.
articles.abstract: The president’s campaign against the Mueller report and its author is a road map of what is likely to lie ahead.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Over four decades in public life, President Trump has sought to bend business, real-estate and political rivals to his will. Facts that cut against his position have been declared false. Witnesses who have questioned his motives have been declared dishonest. Critics of his behavior are part of a corrupt, shadowy effort aiming to damage him.
articles.byline: By Maggie Haberman

articles.headline: Byron Allen Spares No One in Accusing Comcast of Racial Bias
articles.snippet: The black entrepreneur has gone after civil rights groups and other black leaders to make his case. Some fear that protections dating to 1866 are in jeopardy.
articles.abstract: The black entrepreneur has gone after civil rights groups and other black leaders to make his case. Some fear that protections dating to 1866 are in jeopardy.
articles.lead_paragraph: He broke into the entertainment business as a teenager, playing comedy clubs in Los Angeles and making his first appearance on “The Tonight Show” at age 18. He gained fame as a host of the 1980s NBC hit “Real People” before founding Entertainment Studios in 1993. That company has grown into an empire, with a film division and nearly two dozen television properties, including the Weather Channel, which it acquired last year for $300 million.
articles.byline: By John Eligon

articles.headline: Elizabeth Warren Has Done the Hard Part. Now Comes the Harder Part.
articles.snippet: All summer, she was soaring, slinging buzzy plans and climbing in the polls. It’s not summer anymore.
articles.abstract: All summer, she was soaring, slinging buzzy plans and climbing in the polls. It’s not summer anymore.
articles.lead_paragraph: VINTON, Iowa — Elizabeth Warren motors onstage at her campaign events like she is being chased: arm-pump, arm-pump, mid-jog wave. O.K.! Let’s get this thing going.
articles.byline: By Matt Flegenheimer

articles.headline: In Blockbuster Era, No Room at the Box Office for the Middlebrow
articles.snippet: Midbudget films are being ignored by audiences, who increasingly go to theaters only to see big franchise movies.
articles.abstract: Midbudget films are being ignored by audiences, who increasingly go to theaters only to see big franchise movies.
articles.lead_paragraph: If you walked into ArcLight Cinemas in Sherman Oaks, Calif., on Friday looking for a movie to watch, you would have been greeted by a digital sign listing these offerings:
articles.byline: By Brooks Barnes

articles.headline: A Split Decision From Congress Will Leave Voters With Final Say on Trump
articles.snippet: Unlike Presidents Richard M. Nixon or Bill Clinton, Mr. Trump will face an election after his impeachment battle if he isn’t removed from office.
articles.abstract: Unlike Presidents Richard M. Nixon or Bill Clinton, Mr. Trump will face an election after his impeachment battle if he isn’t removed from office.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When it was all over and the witnesses had testified and the speeches were done, President Trump pronounced himself satisfied with the show. “We had a tremendous week with the hoax,” he declared on Friday as he addressed a room of collegiate athletes. “That’s really worked out incredibly well.”
articles.byline: By Peter Baker

articles.headline: Navy Is Said to Proceed With Disciplinary Plans Against Edward Gallagher
articles.snippet: Top military officials threatened to resign or be fired if their plans to remove Chief Gallagher from the SEALs were halted by President Trump, administration officials said.
articles.abstract: Top military officials threatened to resign or be fired if their plans to remove Chief Gallagher from the SEALs were halted by President Trump, administration officials said.
articles.lead_paragraph: The secretary of the Navy and the admiral who leads the SEALs have threatened to resign or be fired if plans to expel a commando from the elite unit in a war crimes case are halted by President Trump, administration officials said Saturday.
articles.byline: By Maggie Haberman, Helene Cooper and Dave Philipps

articles.headline: With Boeing in Cross Hairs, Lion Air Gets a Pass on Poor Safety Record
articles.snippet: A focus on Boeing after two fatal crashes has given cover to an Indonesian air carrier with global ambitions — a company that will neither fully admit to, nor swiftly address, its safety issues.
articles.abstract: A focus on Boeing after two fatal crashes has given cover to an Indonesian air carrier with global ambitions — a company that will neither fully admit to, nor swiftly address, its safety issues.
articles.lead_paragraph: When things go wrong, those in power often promise to make it right. But do they? In this series, The Times investigates to see if those promises were kept.
articles.byline: By Hannah Beech and Muktita Suhartono

articles.headline: Internet Companies Prepare to Fight the ‘Deepfake’ Future
articles.snippet: Researchers are creating tools to find A.I.-generated fake videos before they become impossible to detect. Some experts fear it is a losing battle.
articles.abstract: Researchers are creating tools to find A.I.-generated fake videos before they become impossible to detect. Some experts fear it is a losing battle.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Several months ago, Google hired dozens of actors to sit at a table, stand in a hallway and walk down a street while talking into a video camera.
articles.byline: By Cade Metz

articles.headline: A White Officer Shoots a Black Colleague, Deepening a Racial Divide
articles.snippet: Although they all wear blue, white officers and black officers experience strained relations in St. Louis’s Police Department.
articles.abstract: Although they all wear blue, white officers and black officers experience strained relations in St. Louis’s Police Department.
articles.lead_paragraph: ST. LOUIS — Milton Green was in the driveway of his home on St. Louis’s North Side one night when he suddenly found the barrel of a gun pointed in his direction. Right away, his police training kicked in: He pulled a badge from beneath his T-shirt and grabbed ahold of his service weapon, a 9-millimeter Beretta.
articles.byline: By John Eligon

articles.headline: Leaked China Files Show Internment Camps Are Ruled by Secrecy and Spying
articles.snippet: A secret document reflects leaders’ struggle to manage Xinjiang sites swelling with Muslim detainees.
articles.abstract: A secret document reflects leaders’ struggle to manage Xinjiang sites swelling with Muslim detainees.
articles.lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — As the government accelerated mass detentions of Muslim minorities in northwest China, a senior official issued a secret directive giving detailed orders for how the rapidly expanding indoctrination camps holding them should be managed.
articles.byline: By Austin Ramzy and Chris Buckley

articles.headline: Hong Kong Election Results Give Democracy Backers Big Win
articles.snippet: A surge in voting, especially by young people, allowed democracy advocates to win many more seats on local councils.
articles.abstract: A surge in voting, especially by young people, allowed democracy advocates to win many more seats on local councils.
articles.lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — Pro-democracy candidates buoyed by months of street protests in Hong Kong won a stunning victory in local elections on Sunday, as record numbers voted in a vivid expression of the city’s aspirations and its anger with the Chinese government.
articles.byline: By Keith Bradsher, Austin Ramzy and Tiffany May

articles.headline: French Luxury Giant LVMH Nears Deal to Buy Tiffany
articles.snippet: The $16 billion acquisition would be the largest ever in the luxury sector.
articles.abstract: The $16 billion acquisition would be the largest ever in the luxury sector.
articles.lead_paragraph: LVMH Moët Hennessy Louis Vuitton will be having a lot of breakfasts at Tiffany’s — as well as lunches, dinners and board meetings.
articles.byline: By Vanessa Friedman, Elizabeth Paton and Andrew Ross Sorkin

articles.headline: How Taylor Swift Dragged Private Equity Into Her Fight Over Music Rights
articles.snippet: The Carlyle Group, an investor in her catalog, has stepped in to encourage talks between Ms. Swift and Scooter Braun, who now controls her old label.
articles.abstract: The Carlyle Group, an investor in her catalog, has stepped in to encourage talks between Ms. Swift and Scooter Braun, who now controls her old label.
articles.lead_paragraph: A little over a week ago, a troubling alert appeared on the smartphone of an executive at the private equity giant the Carlyle Group: The firm had been invoked by Taylor Swift.
articles.byline: By Kate Kelly, Joe Coscarelli and Ben Sisario

articles.headline: Esper Demands Resignation of Navy Secretary Over SEAL Case
articles.snippet: Richard Spencer, the Navy secretary, differed in his private and public statements, the defense secretary said. Others said he angered President Trump by publicly disagreeing with him and threatening to resign.
articles.abstract: Richard Spencer, the Navy secretary, differed in his private and public statements, the defense secretary said. Others said he angered President Trump by publicly disagreeing with him and threatening to resign.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Defense Secretary Mark T. Esper demanded the resignation of the Navy’s top civilian leader on Sunday, an abrupt move aimed at ending an extraordinary dispute between President Trump and his own senior military leadership over the fate of a SEAL commando in a war crimes case.
articles.byline: By Helene Cooper, Maggie Haberman and Dave Philipps

articles.headline: Why Giuliani Singled Out 2 Ukrainian Oligarchs to Help Look for Dirt
articles.snippet: Inside a strategy to leverage damaging information on Joe Biden from foreign citizens who were politically powerful — and legally vulnerable.
articles.abstract: Inside a strategy to leverage damaging information on Joe Biden from foreign citizens who were politically powerful — and legally vulnerable.
articles.lead_paragraph: VIENNA — They were two Ukrainian oligarchs with American legal problems. One had been indicted on federal bribery charges. The other was embroiled in a vast banking scandal and was reported to be under investigation by the F.B.I.
articles.byline: By Jo Becker, Walt Bogdanich, Maggie Haberman and Ben Protess

articles.headline: Black Voters to Black Candidates: Representation Is Not Enough
articles.snippet: Joe Biden leads with black voters, and Elizabeth Warren and Bernie Sanders are making better inroads with younger ones than Kamala Harris and Cory Booker. In interviews, voters rejected the idea that racial representation equated to change.
articles.abstract: Joe Biden leads with black voters, and Elizabeth Warren and Bernie Sanders are making better inroads with younger ones than Kamala Harris and Cory Booker. In interviews, voters rejected the idea that racial representation equated to change.
articles.lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — Chyna Hester knew what she was supposed to say.
articles.byline: By Astead W. Herndon

articles.headline: Corruption Inquiry Spreads to U.A.W. Lakeside Resort
articles.snippet: A dozen union officials have been charged or convicted in a sprawling federal investigation.
articles.abstract: A dozen union officials have been charged or convicted in a sprawling federal investigation.
articles.lead_paragraph: ONAWAY, Mich. — The United Auto Workers union is based in Detroit, but its spiritual home lies 250 miles to the north, in a dense and remote forest on the shore of Black Lake.
articles.byline: By Neal E. Boudette

articles.headline: U.S. Resumes Large-Scale Operations Against ISIS in Northern Syria
articles.snippet: After a lull of several weeks, American troops and Syrian Kurdish fighters are once again conducting large-scale counterterrorism missions.
articles.abstract: After a lull of several weeks, American troops and Syrian Kurdish fighters are once again conducting large-scale counterterrorism missions.
articles.lead_paragraph: MANAMA, Bahrain — United States troops have resumed large-scale counterterrorism missions against the Islamic State in northern Syria, military officials say, nearly two months after President Trump’s abrupt order to withdraw American troops opened the way for a bloody Turkish cross-border offensive.
articles.byline: By Eric Schmitt

articles.headline: Uber Is Fighting to Survive in London After Losing Its License
articles.snippet: The company is at odds with regulators and drivers of traditional cabs in its most lucrative European market.
articles.abstract: The company is at odds with regulators and drivers of traditional cabs in its most lucrative European market.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — Uber suffered a major blow on Monday after London transportation authorities made a surprise decision to not extend its taxi operating license because of persistent safety problems, throwing into question whether the company can continue operating in its most lucrative European market.
articles.byline: By Adam Satariano and Amie Tsang

articles.headline: Charles Schwab to Buy TD Ameritrade as Free Trading Takes Over
articles.snippet: The merger would create a brokerage giant with roughly $5 trillion in assets as the industry copes with zero commissions on stock trades.
articles.abstract: The merger would create a brokerage giant with roughly $5 trillion in assets as the industry copes with zero commissions on stock trades.
articles.lead_paragraph: More than 40 years ago, Charles Schwab pioneered discount investing — an upstart firm championing cheaper broker services for the little guy.
articles.byline: By Tara Siegel Bernard and Matt Phillips
